===History===
  +
In relation to the [[Islamic Caliphate]], some Modernists argue there was no glorious history as the first three [[Caliphs]] were assassinated. Furthermore, Spain, Africa and Persia were autonomous at different points in history resulting in there being no one [[Caliphate]] state, contradicting traditional historiography which relates the [[Umayyad]], [[Abbasid]] and [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] Caliphates as maintaining general political and territorial integrity with fragmentation and divisions being the exception.{{Fact|date=December 2008}}
  +   +
===Politics===
  +
Modernists believe Islam is not an ideology but a faith and has no specific prescriptions for modes of governance, as a plethora of approaches to government have been used throughout Muslim history.{{Fact|date=August 2008}} Unlike Christianity, they argue Muslim history has not battled for the separation of church and state since clerics were almost always a separate entity from the rulers.{{Fact|date=August 2008}} Many Modernists advocate Western secular politics, namely, Democracy.
